title: Serif confusion
content:
And this is...?

(More cool work here [http://www.leslie-david.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122034210/http:/www.leslie-david.com/ "http://www.leslie-david.com/") if anyone’s interested)

 [‹ (x) Mid-20th-Century wide serif book face - Estienne {crossgrove}](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122034210/http:/www.typophile.com/node/47818 "Go to previous forum topic") [Looking for the fine brush script face Magoo ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122034210/http:/www.typophile.com/node/47669 "Go to next forum topic")
author: armin

comments.content:
Hi Armin,

looks like some bold [Baskerville](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122034210/http:/www.myfonts.com/search?search%5Btext%5D=Baskerville) – not sure which one.  
F

If I had to guess I would pick [ITC New Baskerville Bold](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122034210/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/itc-new-baskerville/). The descender length on the ’y’ looks longer, and the tail of the ’t’ is shorter than the Monotype version for example, and seems to match the sample.

- Mike Yanega
